Award.AwardTitle: OPT-PDE Analysis and FRET Imaging of Constitutive Connections between Physics and Chemistry in Live Cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding molecular transport and interaction within single live cells is crucial for advancing life sciences and medicine. This project integrates mathematics with live-cell imaging to study diffusion tensor maps and the relationship between molecular transport and interaction in live cells. For this purpose, mathematical theory and computational algorithms will be developed for applications in image-based quantitative biology. This project integrates research with education and will provide research training opportunities for students. An annual summer workshop, featuring computational mathematics, live cell imaging, and quantitative biology, will be organized for graduate and undergraduate students. Members of underrepresented groups will be encouraged to participate in both the research training and workshop activities. Outreach activities will bring the project's laboratory research results to high school students.

The research goal of this project is to establish governing equations connecting physics and chemistry in live cells. Molecular diffusion and transport are fundamental processes in biology, biochemistry, and physics. However, the construction of subcellular diffusion maps in living cells based on imaging data remains a challenge. This project will develop an optimization model problem with partial differential equation constraints (OPT-PDE) to compute the diffusion map of intracellular molecules with high spatiotemporal resolution in live cells. Meanwhile, this project will apply fluorescence resonant energy transfer (FRET)-based biosensors to visualize subcellular molecular activities. The correlative FRET imaging microscopy (CFIM) technology will then be employed to evaluate the connection between the subcellular diffusion and the molecular activity imaged by FRET in live cells. Specifically, the protein tyrosine kinases Src and FAK will be selected as examples to demonstrate this connection. Therefore, the results of this project will reveal the spatiotemporal connection between biochemical activities and biophysical properties of desired molecules in live cells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Molecular diffusion and transport are fundamental processes in biology, biochemistry, and physics. However, the reconstruction of subcellular diffusion maps based on imaging data remains a tremendous challenge. To estimate subcellular diffusion, we have developed a general optimization framework with the diffusion equation as constraints (OPT-PDE) to solve for a spatially piecewise constant and anisotropic diffusion map. This diffusion analysis software “diffusion_analysis” has been published at GitHub. Furthermore, to provide direct evidence and quantitatively evaluate the connection between molecular diffusion/transport and biochemical activity in live cells, we have interfaced the OPT-PDE solver algorithm with our live-cell image analysis software Fluocell. We applied the diffusion analysis module to quantify different diffusion rates of the tyrosine kinase Lck in live T cells, and found that Lck diffusion rates are anti-correlated with its kinase activities visualized with a new Lck biosensor. Indeed, the diffusion-based image analysis method allowed us to unravel the biophysical role of Lck tyrosine phosphorylation in guiding its biophysical intermolecular interactions to mediate kinase activation.

Other tyrosine kinases, Src and FAK, have been shown to play crucial roles in a variety of cellular processes. The molecular interactions and biological functions of Src/FAK in live cells are largely dependent on their sub-cellular environment, possibly due to the different sets of mediator molecules and subsequently different interaction patterns at different sub-cellular locations. We have developed the CFIM analysis methods for the quantitative analysis of spatiotemporal molecular inter-regulation in live cells. We applied the CFIM analysis to study the regulation of enzymatic Src kinase on dynamic focal adhesion, as well as the correlation between Src kinase activity and cell protrusion. We have also developed focal adhesion targeted FRET biosensors (FAT-FAK and FAT-Src) to monitor the kinase activity of Src and FAK locally at focal adhesion sites during the adhesion process of cancer cells. This analysis provides quantitative information on the interrelation between hierarchical molecular functions and motilities. Furthermore, we have developed our live-cell ratiometric image analysis software package Fluocell with a high throughput functionality. Fluocell has been utilized to perform ratiometric analysis of live-cell images illuminated by our new Fyn kinase and histone methylation H3K9me3 FRET biosensors to visualize and quantify the dynamic molecular activities in cancer cells. This software package has been widely used in our group and by our collaborators and published at GitHub. 

In summary, our project integrates leading-edge mathematical science with quantitative live cell imaging, to provide a general and systematic approach to reconstruct diffusion tensor maps as well as constitutive relations between physical and chemical properties of functional molecules with high spatiotemporal resolution. The applications of the work are anticipated in computational biology, cell biology, biophysics and biochemistry.

Broader Impacts: We believe in the value of integrating research and education. We are especially committed to ensuring that the next generation, and particularly underrepresented groups including minorities and women have the opportunity and encouragement to work in cutting-edge interdisciplinary research. For this project, besides developing courses and nurturing graduate and undergraduate students, a significant effort has also been invested to provide the fascinating research opportunity to local high-school students. Furthermore, workshops have been organized at the University of California, San Diego campus for postdoctoral researchers and graduate/undergraduate students in the years of 2015, 2017 and 2018. The workshops integrate research and education, featuring advanced topics in optimization, differential equations, live cell imaging, and quantitative biology. Lectures, experimental demonstrations, and cutting-edge-facility tours were also organized.
